column1: What is the normal percentage of the neutrophils out of the circulating leukocytes in healthy adults?
column8: Neutrophils are normally the most abundant leukocytes in adults (about 60–70%).

column1: What is the normal percentage of the lymphocytes out of the circulating leukocytes in healthy adults?
column8: Lymphocytes are typically about 20–40% of circulating leukocytes in healthy adults.

column1: What is the normal percentage of the monocytes out of the circulating leukocytes in healthy adults?
column8: Monocytes normally constitute about 5–8% of circulating leukocytes.

column1: What is the normal percentage of the eosinophils out of the circulating leukocytes in healthy adults?
column8: Eosinophils are normally a small fraction, roughly 1–4% of leukocytes.

column1: What is the normal percentage of the basophils out of the circulating leukocytes in healthy adults?
column8: Basophils are the rarest granulocytes in blood, typically <1%.

column1: What is the approximate maximum thickness of the glycocalyx (cell coat) on the plasma membrane?
column8: The glycocalyx is a carbohydrate-rich coat; in many cells it can reach about 100 nm in thickness.

column1: How often is the glycocalyx (cell coat) typically renewed?
column8: Glycocalyx components are dynamic and are renewed frequently, commonly described as every 6–8 hours.
